text:
When you hear an interesting fact like “our
euphoric feelings can come from our central

nervous system producing endorphins” you
don’t often stop and think of the scientists
who did years of research to make that discovery.

We’re going to go behind the facts and take
a look at the scientists who discovered them.

The Misinformation Effect is where our recollection
of events becomes less accurate over time,

because information after the event interferes
with our original memory.

One person behind this effect is American
psychologist Elizabeth Loftus.

In 1990, Loftus was asked to provide an expert
testimony in a case where a woman rediscovered

a childhood memory of a murder, but the repressed
memory was found during a therapy session
and was the only evidence for the case.

The case led Loftus to test the idea that
vivid memories could be implanted in our mind
simply by suggesting they happened.

In one of her studies, she discussed with
participants a time they became lost at the
mall as a child.

25% of participants came to believe that they
had truly been lost in the mall.

They even fabricated detailed memories surrounding
the event that were not discussed with her.

Loftus has since testified in over 250 cases,
and as a result of her work, we know there’s
no such thing as a memory locker.

There are little caps at the end of our DNA
strands called telomeres, that protect our
chromosomes.

Each time our cells divide, the telomeres
get shorter and over time, having shorter
telomeres is associated with ageing and mortality.

In 1984, Australian scientist Elizabeth Blackburn
was instrumental in discovering telemorase,
an enzyme that repairs telomeres.

Blackburn and her colleagues won a Nobel Prize
for the discovery in 2009.

She’s since discovered many illnesses are
related to shortened telomeres.

People with heart disease, for example, have
shorter telomeres than their peers without
heart disease.

Basically, her discovery may redefine how
we look at illness.

Sadly, it’s predicted 1 in 85 people will
suffer from Alzheimer's Disease by 2050.

Although two molecules from the root of a
native Indian plant can eliminate Alzheimer’s

symptoms and reverse the buildup of plaque
in the brain.

An Indian scientist behind the 2012 study,
Vij-ay-alash-mi Ra-vin-dra-nath, showed these
effects in the brains of mice.

It’s a beginning stage, but since current
medication is synthetic and only slows the

effects of Alzheimer's, the discovery could
benefit the lives of millions of people.

And just in case you were wondering, we know
that producing endorphins leads to euphoric

feelings because American neuroscientist Candace
Pert discovered our brain’s opiate receptor
in 1972, as a graduate student.

It’s the cellular site where our body’s
painkillers and blissful endorphins bond with
cells to do their thing.

If you know a cool story of a scientist behind
a fact or discovery, let me now down below
in the comments.
